p: We then examined whether p1 typing results correlated with the presence of MR mutations in isolates and found that the presence of MR mutations in isolates was highly dependent on p1 gene type. Most of type 1 isolates harbored MR mutations (204/223 isolates, 91.5%). In contrast, only one type 2 (1/102, 1%) and five type 2c (5/84, 6%) isolates harbored A2063G mutation ( Table 4). The total isolates with MR mutation in type 2 lineage (2, 2a, 2b, and 2c) was 3.1% (6/193). Thus, the presence of MR mutations was strongly determined by the p1 type (between type 1 and 2 lineages) ( P < 0.01, Fisherâ€™s exact test).
